title: German police and auxiliaries in civilian clothes look on as a group of Jewish women are forced to undress before their execution.
A sign marking a mass grave in Bergen-Belsen.
Jewish women and children from Subcarpathian Rus who have been selected for death at Auschwitz-Birkenau, walk toward the gas chambers.
Raoul Wallenberg in his office at the Swedish legation.
A diagram of the medical chain of command in the Third Reich, drawn up as evidence for the Medical Case (Doctors') Trial in Nuremberg.
Hungarian gendarme exhume corpses of Jews from a mass grave.  The victims were killed in the Maros Street Hospital massacre.
Jewish youth at work in a shoemaking workshop in the Glubokoye ghetto.
The Brust and Schwarz families celebrate the upcoming marriage of Livia and Elek (pictured center).
An American soldier stands near the corpses of Dachau guards who were executed just after the liberation of the camp.
Two Jewish men at forced labor clearing rubble in Konskowola.
Lea Sheindla Leiblich holding her son, Tuvia Erlich, in the Eggenfelden displaced persons camp.
Philipp Auerbach, Chairman of the Association of Jewish Communities in Bavaria meets with a group of unidentified men.
View of St. Andrew's church in Kiev.
Three German-Jewish refugees stand in front of a barracks in the Kitchener camp.

Unauthorized Salvadoran citizenship certificate issued to Frajda (nee Krajkemann) Kiper (b. 1889 in Warsaw) and her daughter Riwa Kiper (born January 16, 1930 in Warsaw) by George Mandel-Mantello, First Secretary of the Salvadoran Consulate in Switzerland and sent to their residence in the children's home at 34 rue des Patriotes in Brussels.
Unauthorized Salvadoran citizenship certificate issued to Betty Lewenstein (b. January 25, 1876 in Amsterdam) by George Mandel-Mantello, First Secretary of the Salvadoran Consulate in Switzerland.

Unauthorized Salvadoran citizenship certificate issued to Ludwig Isakowits (b. 1913 in Faln-Zlatina)  by George Mandel-Mantello, First Secretary of the Salvadoran Consulate in Switzerland and sent to his residence in Faln-Zlatina.
Portrait of Endre Feigenbaum (later Prof. Andrej Fabry), a member of the Hungarian Zionist youth resistance organization.
Studio portrait of Bela Ackerman.
Studio portrait of Miklosne [wife of Miklos] Vertes, who owned a needlepoint store.

First two pages of the ethical will of Elkhanan Elkes, the chairman of the Kovno ghetto Jewish Council.  Elkes wrote the letter between October 19 and November 11, 1943, and had it smuggled out of the ghetto to his two grown children, who were living in England at the time.
Portrait of Jewish refugee child Hans Stern outside the Chabannes children's home.
Portrait of Reb Shlomo Zlotnik of Eisiskes.
Group portrait of five Jewish soldiers serving in the Polish army.
Hannah Dubczanski reads a newspaper in her newly rebuilt house on Vilna Street.
Three Romani men pose in front of a horse-drawn caravan.
Survivors of the Hanover-Ahlem concentration camp prepare food inside of a building.
Members of the Slomnicki family pose together on the grass.

The ruins of the former Warsaw ghetto Jewish Council building after its destruction by the SS during the ghetto uprising.  The original German caption reads "The building of the former Jewish Council."

Mania Gryniewicz, seated, with her children, Hania and Adam.  Gutman, her husband, is on the left.  First from right is Victor Jakubowicz, Mania's brother, who visited from Belgium. Second from left is Mosze Stawski, brother-in-law of Kalman Jakubowicz.
View of a display case featuring a dress worn by a Romani woman from Czechoslovakia, on the fourth floor of the permanent exhibition in the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum.
Three former Jewish partisans pose in the Vilna ghetto soon after the liberation.
Major Irving Heymont converses with David Ben-Gurion during his visit to the Landsberg displaced persons camp.
A letter that is written on the verso of a color drawing created by Hans Ament, a Jewish refugee child living in the children's home in Izieu.
A Jewish family from Vilna gathers outside a wooden cottage for a group portrait while on vacation in Podbrodzie.
Portrait of three young people in the Bedzin ghetto, one of whom is wearing a Jewish star.
Group portrait of a second grade class in a religious elementary school in Nuremberg, Germany.
Chief Soviet prosecutor General R.A. Rudenko speaks at the International Military Tribunal trial of war criminals at Nuremberg.

Supporters of the Socialist Party of Germany (SPD) cheer as M. Loebe, the former president of the Reichstag, delivers a speech in the Lustgarten in front of the Berlin Cathedral, condemning Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party.
Group portrait of Jewish DPs in the Cremona displaced persons camp.

Verso of the Lithuanian Safe Conduct Pass issued to Markus Nowogrodzki. This pass was eventually bound into a passport. It contains Sugihara ink stamps, two Russian transit visas, a Lithuanian stamp, an American non-immigration visa, and a Seattle entry stamp.
Jan Kostanski (left) shares a park bench in the Saski Gardens with Wladek Cykiert.
A Jewish grandfather poses outside with his baby grandson.
A little girl poses with a stuffed animal on the staircase in the Hall of Witness at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum.
Max Weilheimer lights Channuka candles in the Gurs internment camp.
Displaced persons walk down the main street of their camp, probably a former concentration camp.  A watch tower can be seen in the background and barbed wire on the sides.
Card with a drawing of a red star, photographs and the initials NOB (the Yugoslav Partisan movement).
Three young Jewish friends pose by a bicycle.
